Award.AwardTitle: Developmental Co-dependence and Embryonic Programming of Cardiac and Renal Systems Function in Vertebrates - II
Award.AbstractNarration: This project has three distinct but inter-related themes, each building on the next through an integrated physiological systems approach. Initially, the lab will explore, for the very first time, the embryonic interactions of two major systems - the cardiovascular system (CVS) and the renal system - and how their developmental plans are codependent upon each other as the vertebrate embryo develops. Also to be investigated is the developmental onset of the normal regulatory interactions between the CVS and renal system, including determination of developmental periods of greatest sensitivity to external stressors- the so-called "critical windows". Third, the enigmatic field of delayed phenotype alteration -so-called "fetal programming"- of the CVS and kidneys will be explored. The hypotheses will be tested by applying environmental and/or pharmaceutical stressors to the embryo and then assessing the physiological changes in the embryo and adult bird. The experiments will also begin to identify underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms that manifest in structural and functional modifications. This work transcends the typical "intrasystem" approach of most studies of structure/function relationships in developing vertebrates. Indeed, it represents one of the first experimental programs to look across - rather than just within - physiological systems in the developing vertebrate embryo. This study will greatly improve the understanding of the development of the embryonic CV and renal systems, and when and how these systems first begin their interactions, making important advances in the ontogeny of physiological regulation between, rather than just within, systems. An enhanced understanding of embryonic physiology in vertebrates - especially phenomena like developmental plasticity and particularly fetal programming - is a vital prerequisite for the eventual development of corrective procedures for congenital defects in human fetuses and even embryos. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive state-of-the-art training in the Developmental Physiology and Genetics program at the University of North Texas and interactions with researchers at the Universidad Autonoma del Estado de Mexico will provide them with important cultural and international perspectives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sylvia Branum, PhD student, investigating how changes in the environment alter renal performance and structure and how this alterations influence cardiovascular structure and performance. 

  • Eggs incubated in low (20%) humidity lost a significant amount of water compared to control (60%) and high humidity incubated eggs (85%). The lowered incubation humidity decreased wet body mass in later stage embryos (D17,18,19) and hatchlings. Dry conditions dehydrated the embryos but the actual growth of the embryo wasn't affected by the humidity levels during development. High incubation humidity didn't show any of these effects on body mass of embryos. Heart mass wasn't affected by incubation humidity but it significantly decreased kidney mass in both low and high incubation humidity groups, indicating the humidity of the environment during development does affect kidney development without affecting the heart. Embryos incubated in low humidity have increased blood osmolality compared to the control and high humidity groups. Mean blood lactate concentrations were increased during the later part of development for both of the treatment groups as well. However, blood gas variables and other hematological measurements, during the last half of incubation were not affected by the humidity treatments. We found smaller hatchlings from the eggs that were incubated in low humidity but these hatchlings recovered from this decrease in mass by 1-2 days post hatch. We have found that lower incubation humidity lowers hatchability and are currently still adding data to support this finding.
  • Salt-loading embryos altered the normal osmoregulation of chicken embryos throughout development. We found that increasing the salt concentration during development and exposing the embryos earlier in development resulted in smaller embryos than the other groups. There is a possible decrease in heart and kidney wet mass in earlier injection days while there was no change in embryos injected later in development. The CAM showed incomplete and unhealthy development in embryos that were exposed to high salt levels during development. Mortality rates of embryos also increased with the higher salt concentration exposures. Further investigation continues on the glomerular filtration rate and how the high salt levels are affecting the kidneys of the salt-loaded embryos.

Josele Flores completed research for his dissertation “Cardiovascular fetal programming in quail (Colinus virginianus), an avian comparative model”. During his research supported by this NSF grant he was able to establish an avian model for fetal programming through the use of hypoxia. The species selected for this purpose was the bobwhite quail.  He was able to evaluate and asses the effects of gestational hypoxia in the system of adult birds. The evaluation focused on the cardiovascular system showing evidence of hypertension, dilated cardiomyopathy and vascular endothelial dysfunction. He was able to present his data at the Experimental Biology conference in San Diego California in 2013 with very good input. He was able to start working on two manuscripts to be published next year. Josele had the opportunity to work and mentor three undergraduate students involving them in research and science. Finally his research and learnings helped him become a professor at the Autonomous University of the State of Mexico in Toluca Mexico and to continue collaborating with professors in the US.

Melissa Lewallen completed research for her thesis defense “Chronic hypoxia and hyperoxia modifies morphology and VEGF expression of the lungs of the developing chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus)” supported by this NSF grant. She was able to determine how pulmonary structure and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) concentration can be altered in D16 and D18 chicken embryos during development through the use of hypoxia (15% O2), normoxia (21% O2) and hyperoxia (30% O2). She found that  body mass was directly correlated with incubation oxygen level, but neither oxygen level affected lung wet mass at days 16 and 18. She also found that hypoxia had little or no effect on pulmonary structures, however it did increase by ~65% the proportion in cross-section of the total lung occupied by parabronchi on D18. Hyperoxia caused few significant changes in pulmonary structure. Normoxia decreased by ~30% the pulmonary VEGF concentration on D18 while hypoxia increased it by ~35-75% on both D16 and D18. These data suggest that pulmonary gross morphology development in the chicken embryo, while moderately plastic, isn't profoundly affected by oxygen incubation level. This research was published in the “Respiratory Physiology & Neurobiology” Journal in 2015.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2016
Modified by: Warren W Burggren

Eggs incubated in low (20%) humidity lost a significant amount of water compared to control (60%) and high humidity incubated eggs (85%). The lowered incubation humidity decreased wet body mass in later stage embryos (D17,18,19) and hatchlings. Further investigation continues on the glomerular filtration rate and how the high salt levels are affecting the kidneys of the salt-loaded embryos.
